title: Trump Says Ratcliffe Won't Be Nominee for Director of National Intelligence
summary: President says he will announce new pick shortly. WASHINGTON-President Trump said Friday that Rep. John Ratcliffe wouldn't be his nominee for director of national intelligence, after lawmakers and former intelligence officials raised concerns that the Texas Republican would politicize the nation's spy agencies and key senators quietly lobbied against his selection.

title: Jay Powell's Public Option
summary: The Fed may elbow out a private real-time payments system.. When government seeks to compete with private business, it pays to be skeptical. This is especially true of a Federal Reserve proposal to undercut banks by developing a competing system to process electronic payments. No surprise, Elizabeth Warren loves the idea.

title: Joe Biden's Iraq Memories
summary: The former Vice President omits a few details about his strategic misjudgments.. Foreign policy was barely discussed at the Democratic presidential debates this week, and not in a good way when it was. The main point seemed to be to stop "endless war," which sounds like Donald Trump as a candidate in 2016.

title: Renault in Talks on Nissan Stake, Hopes to Revive Fiat Deal
summary: Executives for the French car maker hope lower stake earns Nissan's support for a Fiat deal. Top executives at Nissan Motor Co. and Renault SA are trying to hash out a deal to reshape their global alliance, a step top executives at the French car company hope will pave the way for merger talks with Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV to resume, according to emails reviewed by The Wall Street Journal and people briefed on the discussions.

title: Protectionist Diplomacy Goes Global
summary: Tokyo is taking after Trump in using coercive trade against Seoul.. When South Korea last week protested Japan's plan to strip its Asian neighbor of preferential trade treatment, no other World Trade Organization members spoke up. Tokyo followed through on Friday, and Seoul said hours later it will remove Japan from its own preferential list.

title: The SEC's 'Carrion' Hawks
summary: A judge blows the whistle on the agency's late hit on Volkswagen.. The Securities and Exchange Commission waited more than two years to sue Volkswagen after the company settled with other government regulators over its emissions deceit, and a federal judge wants to know why. Based on the SEC response, agency staff either were dozing or are deceiving the court and commission.

title: Brazilian Official Is Ousted After Amazonian Deforestation Dispute
summary: President Jair Bolsonaro called data showing an 88% annual rise in Amazonian deforestation a lie, without evidence to support his claim. BRASÍLIA-Brazil's government ousted the chief of the agency that tracks deforestation after President Jair Bolsonaro accused him of lying about rising levels of Amazonian destruction.

title: 737 MAX Safety Tests Covering Increasingly Remote Failure Risks
summary: Reviews of grounded Boeing jet are expanding beyond the automated flight-control system behind two crashes. As Boeing Co. and safety regulators push to complete long-awaited fixes for 737 MAX jets, testing has expanded to cover increasingly unlikely emergencies including potential computer failures pinpointed by overseas authorities, according to U.S. government officials briefed on the details.

title: EU Ministers Select Georgieva as Candidate for IMF Chief
summary: The Bulgarian is chief executive of the World Bank Group. European Union finance ministers have selected their nominee to be the next chief of the International Monetary Fund in a move that would require a change of the institution's rules.

title: Pfizer, Capital One, Apple: Stocks That Defined The Week
summary: Resume Subscription. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite ended the week more than 3% lower after the Federal Reserve decided to cut interest rates and President Trump announced potential new tariffs on Chinese imports.

title: CBS, Viacom Reach Tentative Deal on New Leadership
summary: Working agreement calls for CBS acting chief Joe Ianniello to oversee all of CBS's branded assets and for Viacom boss Bob Bakish to become CEO. CBS Corp. and Viacom Inc. have reached a working agreement on the management team that will lead the combined company in the event of a merger, people familiar with the matter said, resolving a critical question that threatened to stand in the way of a deal.

title: Tariff Fight Knocks Off China as Top U.S. Trading Partner
summary: Data released Friday showed that Mexico was the top trading partner for the first half of the year, followed by Canada. WASHINGTON-The standoff between Washington and Beijing has cost China its position as the U.S.'s top trading partner, a shift that could accelerate as President Trump moves to ratchet up tariffs even more.

title: 'I Know What I Saw' Review: The Rustle in the Trees
summary: A collection of ﬁrsthand sightings of mythical and mysterious creatures in the U.S., from the Oglala Deer Woman to the Texas Lobo Girl.. Farmers on the Mediterranean island of Corsica have been complaining for a long time that something was preying on their sheep and lambs, but no one in authority believed them. In June the predator at last was identified: the "cat-fox" or (in Corsican dialect) "ghjattu volpe," a previously unknown species of large wildcat. If a new creature can turn up on a relatively small island that has been settled for millennia, what, one might ask, could still be lurking in the woods of Maine or Washington state?

title: 'Barnum' Review: The Prince of Humbugs
summary: A 'humbug' is a fake that delights the audience without scamming them. It's sleight of hand, not bait and switch.. Most Americans know the name P.T. Barnum because of the magnificent, eponymous circus that he and James A. Bailey co-launched in 1880, when Barnum was 70. But there was more to this staggeringly energetic impresario than "The Greatest Show on Earth." He was a bundle of contradictions, at once a Jacksonian Democrat and a Lincoln Republican, a tippler and a temperance advocate, a slave-owner and an abolitionist, a self-promoter and an altruist. He was a millionaire who knew bankruptcy, tragedy and failure. He funded hospitals and yet trafficked in freaks. He was a consummate entertainer-and not, contrary to the received idea of him, a huckster or a cheat. He never espoused a philosophy as cynical as "There's a sucker born every minute," a remark erroneously attributed to him. And yet this self-styled "prince of humbugs," this extoller of the fatuous as well as the fabulous, was, in his matchless ability to give the public what it wanted, the canniest, wealthiest American showman of his era.

title: When the Market Meets Morality
summary: Rev. Robert A. Sirico has spent decades defending capitalism from the left. Today the attacks come from the right too.. Grand Rapids, Mich.

title: What Ails the U.S. Press?
summary: The media's lack of interest in the Steele dossier amounts to collusion in a coverup.. A timeworn TV commentator and professor of politics, in the moments before Robert Mueller's testimony began last week on MSNBC, told the audience that Russia's meddling in the 2016 election was an "act of war" by a "sworn enemy of the United States."

title: What Would We Do Without the Word 'Racism'?
summary: The term became pervasive only after discrimination was banned and blacks made significant progress.. If the country had a National Language Commission, and I were appointed commissioner, the first word I would put in cold storage-filed permanently away beside the N-word, the C-word, the K-word and other prohibited words-would be "racism." In our day the word has been used imprecisely, promiscuously, perniciously and well beyond abundantly. If you are politically on the left, racism is what you accuse people of who don't agree with you. If you are on the right, you can accuse them, I suppose, of socialism, but it doesn't carry anything like the same resonance in moral opprobrium or self-awarded virtue as does racism.

title: A Dark Day for Red Tape in the Buckeye State
summary: Ohio's government will start cataloging-and cutting-its hundreds of thousands of regulations.. Ohio Gov. Mike DeWine signed a two-year budget after a hard-fought battle last month between legislators in the Ohio House and Senate. The local media has focused on the 4% income-tax cut and increased spending for education and children's services. Less noticed has been the most ambitious and innovative part of the budget-a regulatory-relief provision.

title: Dad, Did You Achieve All Your Life Goals?
summary: My daughter's question showed me my aims at 21 weren't what they are now.. I don't often get a question that stops me in my tracks. But on a recent vacation, my daughter and I had the rare opportunity to sit down and talk in a relaxed setting. We're at very different stages in our lives. She is 21, going into her senior year of college with the whole world in front of her. I'm 68-most of my friends are retiring.

title: Investors Pull Back from Jack Dorsey's Square-For Now
summary: Drop came after payments company reported disappointing earnings guidance. Jack Dorsey's Square Inc. fell 14% on Friday, but it may just be a course correction for the highflying, financial-technology firm.

title: Legacy Airlines Are Proving They Can Catch Up
summary: British Airways-owner IAG is now more profitable than Europe's budget powerhouse Ryanair. The rise of budget airlines has been the aviation story of the 21st century. But legacy airlines are proving they can fight back. It is a shame investors don't quite believe them.

title: Bot-Like Activity Pushed Divisive Content on Race During Debates
summary: Data shows suspicious social-media accounts targeted Kamala Harris, including with conspiracy theories, during both Democratic gatherings. Hundreds of social-media accounts with bot-like traits promoted misinformation and content aimed at inflaming racial divisions during both nights of Democratic presidential debates, continuing similar activity during the first set of debates in June, according to data analyzed by The Wall Street Journal.

title: Those Cell Towers Don't Build Themselves
summary: It takes engineers like Bill Hilyer to keep your phone connected. Perhaps the biggest question facing the telecommunications industry is which company will be first to roll out the speedier 5G network to customers. Whether a company succeeds in that depends upon the work done by people like Bill Hilyer.

title: Rapper A$AP Rocky Released From Prison in Sweden
summary: President Trump lobbied for the rapper's freedom. American rapper A$AP Rocky, on trial for assault in Sweden, was released on Friday pending a verdict in a case that strained relations between the two nations after President Trump repeatedly called for the defendant's release.

title: Where Did This 'Bull Market' Come From, Anyway?
summary: Investors talk about bull markets, especially the current one, but nobody seems to agree on a definition or where the term came from. Everybody talks about bull and bear markets, especially the current one, often called the longest bull market in history at just under 3,800 days. But nobody seems to agree on an exact definition, or knows where the prevailing ones originated, including many investment professionals.

title: IBM Promises Earnings Boost From Red Hat Deal Starting Next Year
summary: Tech giant sees deal, cloud computing as keys to robust trajectory. International Business Machines Corp. promised its acquisition of open-source software giant Red Hat Inc. would boost earnings starting next year as Chief Executive Ginni Rometty battles to return the 108-year-old tech giant to a growth path.

title: Stocks Suffer Worst Week in Months on Trade Threats
summary: Major indexes decline further on potential for U.S. to extend levies to essentially all Chinese imports. U.S. stocks capped their worst week in months with another decline Friday as investors overlooked a jobs report in line with expectations and focused on threats by President Trump to extend tariffs to essentially all Chinese imports.

title: Inside the Capital One Hack
summary: Most Popular News. The Journal is a podcast about money, business and power, hosted by Kate Linebaugh and Ryan Knutson. The Journal is a co-production from Gimlet Media and The Wall Street Journal.

title: Robespierre and Today's Tyranny of Pronouns
summary: Peggy Noonan draws an astute analogy between the radical purists of the French Revolution and our increasingly strident left-wing elites.. In "What Were Robespierre's Pronouns?" (Declarations, July 27), Peggy Noonan draws an astute analogy between the radical purists of the French Revolution and our increasingly strident left-wing elites. She notes that, as part of their efforts to re-fashion France according to their worldview, Maximilien Robespierre and his cohorts sought not only to impose their political ideology but also their social and religious preferences, and even a new calendar. A critical consequence of this effort to revamp French society was that within two decades most of the radical social changes, unpalatable to large segments of the French, were discarded and France reverted to its traditional mores. Today, as American society is being buffeted by efforts to alter many of our long-held social, religious and sexual values, the lessons of the French Revolution suggest that the question to ask is: How long will it be before many of our traditional American values are resurgent?

title: How Robust Is Religious Liberty in America?
summary: Marci Hamilton opines that the only absolute right guaranteed by the First Amendment is the "right to believe anything you want." But we hardly need a constitution for that.. If the federal courts enforced the Ninth Amendment, as is their plain duty, then most of the issues that separate David French and Marci Hamilton in "Is American Religious Liberty in Peril?" (Review, July 27) would be resolved without reference to the First Amendment. Ms. Hamilton brings up the question of peyote. If the courts took our general right to liberty seriously, the states would have to make an argument capable of withstanding intermediate scrutiny that consuming peyote in a religious ceremony harms the health, safety, morals or general welfare of their citizens. This would be difficult since most studies have found that in that context, it is benign. Likewise, Mr. French's concern about creative people coerced into advocating for positions they consider immoral would be resolved by the enforcement of the right to free association. The enumerated rights in the Constitution aren't supposed to be islands of freedom in a sea of state power but high points in a vast prairie of freedom. But if the courts won't enforce unenumerated rights, people will continue to have unseemly squabbles to gain a place on the islands.

title: ObamaCare's Cadillac Tax Sought to Spread the Cost
summary: The result of not implementing this provision is unreasonably high deductibles and premiums for a small group of people. The group market should share the pain.. I found Brian Blase's "Improve, Don't Repeal, ObamaCare's Cadillac Tax" (op-ed, July 25) totally incredible. This tax was one of the few reasonable items in the bill. It would have shared the pain of the subsidies and negative selection with other demographic groups. Instead the Affordable Care Act put most of the burden on the individual market. The result of not implementing this provision is unreasonably high deductibles and premiums for a small group of people. The group market should share the pain. The Trump administration doing the politically expedient thing overrides being fair to the minority, exactly like its predecessor.

title: On Rights for Machines: 'I Robot' Meets the PC Police
summary: Thank goodness the Rethink Robots' Baxter robots we use at my company are tricolored.. Regarding your Aug. 2 Notable & Quotable on Caroline Klein and David Allan reporting for CNN.com on racism and industrial robots: Thank goodness the Rethink Robotics brand Baxter robots we use at my company are tricolored-red, black and dark gray. All of us were beginning to suspect we might be racists.

title: Treasury Yields Fall to Lowest Since Before 2016 Vote
summary: Government bonds complete arc tracking rise and fall of investors' economic optimism. U.S. government bond yields fell to their lowest levels since before the 2016 presidential election on Friday, completing a remarkable arc tracking the rise and fall of investors' economic optimism.

title: Illinois Lawmakers to Investigate College Financial-Aid Loophole
summary: Families transferred guardianship of their children to a third party, allowing applicants to avoid claiming their parents' incomes. CHICAGO-Illinois lawmakers have scheduled a hearing for next week to investigate a financial-aid loophole that has enabled affluent and middle-class families to access college scholarship money designed to help poor students.

title: The Perfect Saturday in New York: Hop on the Ferry
summary: Thanks to the city's expanded ferry service, you can jump breezily from borough to borough by boat. Here's a day's itinerary with stops for waterfront strolls and a lobster supper. "We were very tired," begins a poem by Edna St. Vincent Millay, a chronicler of New York City's Jazz Age. "We were very merry-We had gone back and forth all night on the ferry." Today, few of New York's ferries run into the wee hours. But over the past three years, the fleet has been expanding under the aegis of NYC Ferry, operated by Hornblower. Four new lines have already launched, including those to Manhattan's Upper East Side and Brooklyn's Bay Ridge. New routes to Staten Island and Coney Island are expected in 2020 and 2021, respectively. And, all the better for some Millay-style madcap bohemia, the ferries come equipped with wine-and-beer bars. Mostly used by commuters working on Wall Street or in Midtown, the ferries beat subways and are an ideal way to spend a sprawling Saturday, starting in one borough and nipping over to others. Buy tickets as you go ($2.75 a ride), and follow my lead:

title: Two Fed Officials Say Economy Didn't Justify Lowering Rates
summary: Boston Fed president, along with leader of Kansas City Fed, were dissenting votes in rate-cut decision. The two Federal Reserve officials who opposed Wednesday's interest-rate cut by the central bank justified their views based on the current state of the economy, in separate statements Friday.

title: Zoltan Merszei, an Immigrant, Won and Soon Lost Top Job at Dow Chemical
summary: Hungarian-born executive led highly successful European growth but clashed with colleagues in U.S.. Zoltan Merszei, who fled Hungary in his 20s, led Dow Chemical Co. 's hugely profitable expansion in Europe in the 1960s and early 1970s. His reward was to be named chief executive of the Midland, Mich.-based company in 1976, when foreigners rarely ran big U.S. companies.

title: NYPD Officer Accused in Eric Garner's Death Should Be Fired, Judge Says
summary: NYPD commissioner expected to terminate Officer Daniel Pantaleo; recommendation 'brings me some relief,' Garner's mother says. A New York Police Department judge has recommended the firing of Officer Daniel Pantaleo, who faced disciplinary charges over the 2014 death of Eric Garner, according to officials with direct knowledge of the decision.

title: Growth Fears Send Copper to Two-Year Low
summary: The metal, a bellwether for the world economy, declined the most this week since August 2018. Copper sank to a two-year low, as renewed trade hostilities between the U.S. and China reinforced fears about the world economy.

title: Portland Archdiocese to Pay Nearly $4 Million to Settle Abuse Claims
summary: Eight men alleged they were sexually assaulted as children by an Oregon priest. The Archdiocese of Portland, Ore., has agreed to pay nearly $4 million to eight men who say they were abused by a priest in the 1970s and '80s.

title: U.S. Signs Agreement Allowing More Beef Into EU
summary: Of the 45,000 tons of non-hormone treated beef allowed into the EU every year, the U.S. will now supply 35,000 tons. WASHINGTON-President Trump cheered an agreement to open the European Union to more U.S. beef exports during a White House event Friday.

title: Logistics Companies Extended Robust Hiring in July
summary: Shipping-focused transportation and warehouse firms added 9,000 jobs in the month despite soft hiring at goods-producing companies. Parcel and freight operators added jobs in big numbers in July, bolstering employment in services aimed largely at the burgeoning market for handling and delivering e-commerce orders.

title: India's Coffee King Struggled to Flourish Off an Elusive Middle Class
summary: Apparent suicide sends message to rivals about counting on India's consumers. NEW DELHI-V.G. Siddhartha sought to transform his Indian coffee-shop empire into a global success story. His apparent suicide has instead highlighted the struggle many companies experience seeking to prosper on the back of India's fast-expanding but cost-conscious middle class.

title: Grandeur of the Modern City
summary: With its interplay between static and moving forms, Joseph Stella's 'Brooklyn Bridge' captures the excitement and majesty of the urban industrial environment..

title: Are Dating Apps All Hot or Not?
summary: Dating apps lead our digital lives, but they don't always lead to love at first swipe. Plenty of people are dating online these days, but that doesn't mean success comes easy.

title: North Korean Missile Tests Break U.N. Rules, Trump Says-But Not His Agreement With Kim
summary: President wrote on Twitter that Mr. Kim wouldn't disappoint him with 'violation of trust'. President Trump conceded that North Korea's recent short-range missile tests might have broken United Nations resolutions but said he didn't consider them a violation of Kim Jong Un's commitments to the U.S. president.

title: China's Power to Boost Global Economy Is Fading
summary: Americans for years have been concerned about Beijing's power, but the new worry is its inability to stimulate the world's economies. Americans have gotten used to worrying about China's power. They may need to start worrying about its powerlessness.

title: Germany's Longest Bond Goes Negative for First Time
summary: Rates on 30-year bunds dip briefly to minus 0.002% as investors seek haven assets. Investors spooked by a revival of trade tensions piled into safe assets on Friday, pushing 30-year German government yields into negative territory for the first time.

title: Hard Questions in Syria About the Civilian Toll of U.S. Strategy
summary: Human rights advocates say that tens of thousands of airstrikes have killed far more noncombatants than the coalition admits.. One day during the final weeks of the U.S.-led coalition's battle to dislodge Islamic State from Raqqa, Syria, in October 2017, Randa Ismail heard two of her brothers say they were going out to fill up a few jerrycans at a well just a block away. The family was running low on water.

title: U.S. Added Jobs at Steady Pace in July
summary: Payrolls rose by 164,000 in July; jobless rate held at 3.7%, near a 50-year-low. WASHINGTON-Steady U.S. hiring growth continued into the second half of 2019, providing a solid foundation for the decadelong economic expansion at a time of global headwinds.

title: Size and Scope Aren't Helping Big Oil
summary: Now is the time in the energy cycle to capitalize on being big, but many businesses are struggling simultaneously, pinching Exxon Mobil and Chevron. Being big isn't always easy.

title: Women's Soccer Pay Battle Enters New Arena: The World Cup Victory Tour
summary: The champion U.S. team and its employer disagreed over pay rate for Saturday's kickoff game. The World Cup-champion U.S. team kicks off its five-game "victory tour" at the Rose Bowl in Pasadena, Calif. on Saturday. But even this celebratory moment is being affected by the team's ongoing pay dispute with its employer, the U.S. Soccer Federation.

title: The Long Reign of Parisian Fashion
summary: Couture has been a source of the city's wealth and prestige for centuries.. In 1665, Louis XIV's finance minister supposedly quipped that as a national moneymaker, fashion was to France what the gold mines of Peru were to Spain. Three and a half centuries later, that hasn't changed. "Paris, Capital of Fashion," a new exhibition running from Sept. 6 to Jan. 4 at The Museum at FIT, New York's Fashion Institute of Technology, shows how Paris has stayed ahead of its couture rivals. The show includes some 100 objects, from a silk whalebone corset made around 1750 to an "electric light" dress complete with bulb to a Christian Dior outfit once owned by Marlene Dietrich.

title: Navigant Consulting to Be Acquired for $1.1 Billion
summary: Chicago-based firm will be combined with Veritas Capital's portfolio company Guidehouse. Navigant Consulting Inc. on Friday said it would be acquired by private-equity firm Veritas Capital for $28 a share in cash, or about $1.1 billion.

title: Honda Reduces Production of Sedans as U.S. Buyers Favor Trucks, SUVs
summary: Toyota, meanwhile, reports strong profit growth in the U.S. on the back of higher SUV sales. TOKYO- Honda Motor Co. said Friday it was suspending one of two shifts on a production line for Accords and three other models at its plant in Marysville, Ohio.

title: Endeavor Group Postpones IPO Until September at Earliest
summary: Talent firm nears deal to buy On Location Experiences for as much as $700 million. Endeavor Group Holdings Inc. is delaying its initial public offering until September, at the earliest, as the parent company of Hollywood's biggest talent agency works to finalize an acquisition.

title: President Trump Signs Spending Bill
summary: Legislation raises federal spending and lifts debt ceiling. President Trump on Friday signed into law the two-year agreement passed by Congress that increases federal spending and lifts the government's borrowing limit.

title: Would You Want Bathroom Tiles That Talk to You?
summary: Designers and homeowners are setting messages like "Howdy" and "You're Beautiful" into washroom-floor tiles. Are chatty floors charming or annoying?. THE CHARMING verbal expressions one finds set into penny tile in the entrances of 19th and early 20th-century commercial establishments are piping up in people's bathrooms today. In an apartment on Manhattan's Upper West Side, blue-gray tiles on the lavatory's white floor spell out "Unicorn Trainer," a reference to the little girl who uses the room. Across town, a rousing "Howdy" greets visitors who walk into a guest bath.

title: Arconic Boosts Outlook, Furthers Cost-Cutting Initiatives
summary: Aluminum parts maker posts quarterly loss, reflecting impairment charge. Arconic Inc. boosted its profit outlook for the year, as strong growth in its aerospace business propels the aluminum-components manufacturer towards a break up by the middle of 2020.

title: The Next Level of Marathon Training Is Here
summary: Elite marathoners don't just wing it when it comes to training. They use high-tech gadgets to hack their bodies and achieve times they once thought impossible. Here's how you can too. I WAS FIVE MILES from the finish line of April's 2019 London Marathon when I started thinking about just how stupid it is to race one of these things. My legs were weak, my side was cramping and, to add insult to literal injury, it was starting to drizzle. Obsessively checking my watch every 5 seconds while counting down to the finish line (hoping it might be willing to meet me halfway), I felt stuck in slow motion-at a point when it was time to pick up the pace. Luckily, I had prepared my body for just this moment.

title: 13 Investing Books to Read on Your Summer Vacation
summary: Fund experts offer their top picks for books on investing, Wall Street history and bitcoin. It's summer vacation and time to catch up on that...investment reading?

title: Why Jobs Growth Must Slow
summary: The slower pace of job growth this year may have more to do with low unemployment than problems abroad. Is the job market slowing because global uncertainties are lapping up against American shores or is it slowing because it has to?

title: Haben Girma Is a Trailblazer for the Deaf and Blind
summary: The Harvard Law graduate and activist has learned to navigate a world that wasn't built with her in mind. Haben Girma would prefer not to be called "inspiring." But as a deafblind woman who lives in defiance of the low expectations many people have for the disabled, it is a word she hears often. The daughter of a refugee from Eritrea and an immigrant from Ethiopia, she surfs, she salsa dances, she climbs glaciers, and in 2013, she became the first deafblind person to graduate from Harvard Law School. (She prefers the term "deafblind," with no hyphen, to suggest that the disability is "a cultural identity, not merely a medical condition.")

title: Are Activist Investors Sexist?
summary: Female CEOs are far more likely to face an activist challenge, new research shows. Vicki Hollub is an engineer who spent time on three continents working her way up to the top of Occidental Petroleum Corp. She doesn't have much experience at M&A, and that has made her an easy target for critics.

title: Gas Glut Weighs on Oil Giants
summary: Exxon, Shell, feel the impact of over-abundance of natural gas. The world's largest oil companies are feeling the financial pressure of a global decline in natural-gas prices.

title: China Faces Limited Options to Retaliate to Latest U.S. Threat
summary: Beijing's potential countermeasures risk damaging the country's already slowing economy and could scare off foreign investment. BEIJING-China threatened to retaliate if the U.S. moves to place fresh tariffs on an additional $300 billion in Chinese goods, though Beijing faces limited options to strike back without hurting its economy.

title: Capital One Breach Highlights Shortfalls of Encryption
summary: Bank says hacker's method 'enabled the decrypting of data'. The Capital One Financial Corp. data theft raises questions about companies' reliance on security practices that fail to fully protect sensitive information from hackers.

title: The Heaven and Hell of a Summer Water Park
summary: A parent's defense of a chaotic way to spend a hot afternoon. Once a year, when it's hot enough to sear a rib-eye atop a Buick, I like to take my family for a day of overpriced artificial hydro-tainment.

title: U.S. Consumers Remained Positive in July
summary: University of Michigan's sentiment index ticks slightly higher despite trade doubts. WASHINGTON-U.S. household sentiment ticked slightly higher in July, holding at a high level despite trade uncertainties.

title: How Does the World's First Porsche Drive? Let's Find Out
summary: The first car to carry Ferdinand Porsche's family name, is "one of the most important objects on four wheels," says Dan Neil. He takes it for a slow, creaky spin in Los Angeles. FERDINAND PORSCHE was an enthusiastic National Socialist party member and Hitler's car guy. Attempts to portray the founder of Porsche as a reluctant Nazi are misguided and unsupported by the evidence. Among other crimes, Porsche directed wartime production in factories using forced labor and guarded by units of the SS. Porsche himself was awarded the rank of SS-Oberführer.

title: Burger King and Popeyes Deliver Higher Sales for RBI
summary: Parent company of burger and chicken chains as well as Tim Hortons plans big international expansion. Burger King and Popeyes Louisiana Kitchen are driving sales for Restaurant Brands International Inc.

title: 'Natural Rivals' Review: To Protect and Conserve
summary: Gifford Pinchot and John Muir understood man's relation to nature in different ways-one practical, one spiritual-but left a shared legacy in glorious forests and vast public lands.. In 1896, the United States was suffering through one of the worst financial crises in its history. American society was bitterly divided, by region, party and class. At the same time, scientists were warning of looming ecological disaster in the nation's forests, but politicians refused to act. In "Natural Rivals," John Clayton relates how, against this backdrop, two giants of environmental history, John Muir and Gifford Pinchot, worked to break the stalemate-in the process reshaping America's idea of its public lands and perhaps even providing a model for how to confront our own impending climatic catastrophe.

title: Jobs Report Does Little to Clarify Fed Outlook Muddled By Escalated Trade Tensions
summary: Steady hiring and wages didn't deter a quarter-point rate cut this week. Worries over escalating trade tensions could more than offset any comfort Federal Reserve officials will take from the latest indication of a healthy U.S. labor market.

title: 'Useful Enemies' Review: Deciphering the Heretics to the East
summary: Christian Europe long vilified the Ottomans, then came to see them as models of rationality.. For nearly 300 years, until the mid-17th century, the Ottoman Empire operated a tribute system known as devshirme-the "collecting." Army officers would descend on the villages of Anatolia and the Balkans and remove male, Christian children as young as 8. Enslaved, forcibly converted to Islam and discouraged from marriage, the boys would receive rigorous physical training and form the ranks of the Janissaries, an elite corps of soldiers directly serving the Ottoman sultan. A few would rise to positions of power, and thus some families paid bribes to secure entry into the system for their male children. For many other families, however, devshirme was viewed as a catastrophe; they did what they could to resist such brutal seizure, including the arrangement of childhood marriages and even disfigurement. Across Christendom, devshirme was considered perhaps the most notorious manifestation of Ottoman despotism.

title: 'Lincoln's Spies' Review: The Union's Eyes and Ears
summary: Pinkerton had worked as a railway detective. In 1861 he got a tip that Lincoln would be in danger on the way to his inauguration .. By definition and disposition, the spy presents a daunting challenge to the historian. Expected to be elusive and deceptive, secret agents prefer to swallow written evidence, not preserve it. Then, if they survive to write memoirs, they often aggrandize their achievements at the expense of truth.

title: Politics: What's Wrong With the Right?
summary: George Will weighs in on the losing battle against progressivism.. For the past half-century George Will has written the most consistently readable and engaging newspaper column in America. Mr. Will is nobody's idea of a movement conservative-he inveighs against politicians, and especially presidents, of both parties-but every scribbler and officeholder on the right has, knowingly or not, been influenced by him. At age 78 he has written a lengthy, tightly reasoned book on the vast subject of American conservatism: "The Conservative Sensibility" (Hachette, 600 pages, $35). Readers on the right, especially, owe it to themselves to consider what he says.

title: Mysteries: Cities and Secrets
summary: A kidnap attempt on a bank teller sets Elvis Cole and Joe Pike racing all over Los Angeles in "A Dangerous Man," while a sniper menaces Manhattan in "City of Windows.". It has been 32 years since Robert Crais wrote his first book featuring the charming private investigator Elvis Cole and his partner, Joe Pike. In those three decades, much has changed in the Southern California that Cole and Pike inhabit. Mr. Crais's latest novel, "A Dangerous Man" (Putnam, 339 pages, $28), makes clear that much has also remained the same: There are still plenty of evil actors around and lots of vulnerable people who need protection from them. And Cole and Pike are still in the business of providing aid and comfort to the oppressed and endangered.

title: Five Best: H.S. Cross on Novels About Boarding School
summary: From the author, most recently, of the novel 'Grievous.'. By Rudyard Kipling (1899)

title: Children's Books: The Giddy Fun of Telling a Story
summary: A new work from Shirley Hughes, who at 92 still shares her joyful art with young readers.. When illustrator Shirley Hughes approached a publisher in 1960 about creating a picture book, she received a cautious response. "I was told at the outset that my drawing was far too quintessentially English to be accepted abroad," she once told an interviewer. "But the publishers were proved very wrong."

title: 'The Ghosts of Eden Park' Review: A Tale of Blood and Bourbon
summary: He was one of Prohibition Chicago's most flamboyant defense attorneys-until he noticed his criminal clients were making a lot more money than he was.. Fans of the defunct HBO series "Boardwalk Empire" may recall George Remus as the moon-faced bootlegger with the amusingly self-regarding habit of referring to himself in the third person, much to the confusion of the young Al Capone. ("What do you think George Remus spent five years doing?" he remarks during their first sit-down. "Ain't you George Remus?" asks his baffled rival.) But while "Scarface" has long since entered the pantheon of mythic American gangsters, the real-life Remus-though once a figure of considerable notoriety-has largely passed into oblivion.

title: The Downside of Diversity
summary: On campus, identity politics has become a dogma that damages independent thinking and the pursuit of truth..

title: Democratic Presidential Race Enters Winnowing Phase
summary: Lower-tier candidates now have four weeks to meet tougher requirements for next debate or risk being further marginalized. For most of the two dozen Democratic presidential candidates, the next four weeks will determine if they can keep their White House hopes alive.

title: The 2020 Democrats Compete to Reject Barack Obama's Legacy
summary: Most of the party's presidential hopefuls seem to view the former president as just another sellout. Perhaps the most telling moment in round two of the Democratic presidential debates this week came in a testy exchange between Cory Booker and Joe Biden. I don't mean the New Jersey senator's memorable put-down of the former vice president over the two men's criminal-justice records: "There's a saying in my community: 'You're dipping into the Kool-Aid, and you don't even know the flavor,'" Mr. Booker said, in a carefully rehearsed dig. Splendidly colorful as that was, I couldn't help wondering which of his "communities" the candidate was referring to: Stanford graduates? Rhodes scholars? Members of the U.S. Senate?

title: Wells Fargo to Tech Vendors: Please Send Us a Check
summary: The bank, trying to cut costs, says tech vendors benefited from its regulatory problems. Wells Fargo & Co., in cost-cutting mode, recently asked outside technology consultants to refund some of the money the bank has spent with them in the past year.

title: The New Airport Congestion: Plane Spotters Crowd Fancy Hotel Bars
summary: The new TWA Hotel at JFK cracks down on miserly aviation hobbyists; 'it was getting crazy crowded'. NEW YORK-At the rooftop pool bar at the new TWA Hotel, nobody watches as the sun sets over the distant Manhattan skyline.

summary: Entrepreneur's shift beyond analog systems in the 1970s gave his firm an edge against bigger rivals. Gearhart Industries Inc. was a hot stock in the 1970s and early 1980s when oil prices were soaring.

title: Bell-Cow Backs and Target-Hog Receivers Are an Endangered Species
summary: Fantasy football keeps getting harder as NFL teams increasingly diversify their rushing and passing attacks to become less reliant on any single player. The basic rules of fantasy football are pretty simple: select the players who are most likely to gain the most yards, catch the most passes, and score the most touchdowns. The problem is that NFL offenses aren't making it easy.

title: The Scandal That Cost Justin Trudeau His Rock-Star Popularity
summary: Resume Subscription. Justin Trudeau did little wrong in his supporters' eyes during his first three years as Canada's prime minister. In the fourth, his popularity has dropped so far his party may lose its majority in October elections.

title: One Cheer for Low Rates
summary: The notion that falling interest rates are good for stocks is based on some flimsy logic. Companies haven't been doing so hot this year, but investors are too busy cheering on low rates to be all that worried.

title: Mountain Bike Getaways Just Got More Enticing
summary: From British Columbia to the Italian Alps, these four places are ideally suited for mountain biking. Plus: why flying with your bike is easier than you think. A FEW YEARS AGO, some friends gleefully informed me they'd arranged to fly to Switzerland with their mountain bikes to ride alpine trails from village to village. The trip sounded legitimately idyllic, but could it really be worth the misery of lugging a bike across the Atlantic? I pictured myself struggling to pack my darling, and dearly priced, two-wheeler. I resented the thought of paying some airline exorbitant excess baggage fees for handlers to toss her hither and thither.

title: Cuban Migrants Are Thwarted in Mexico by New Asylum Rules

title: Canada Exports, Imports Dropped in June
summary: Exports decline 5.1%, the biggest drop in two years; economy manages to record small trade surplus. OTTAWA-Canadian exports and imports fell by the most in two years in June, as activity in crude-oil markets weighed on both sales abroad and foreign purchases.

title: Hong Kong's Government Faces Dissent From Within
summary: Organizers expect more than 1,000 civil servants to attend a rally despite the threat of consequences. HONG KONG-A contentious extradition bill, the police's handling of weekslong protests and city officials' limited response to the public's concerns have provoked a rare wave of dissent from within the government's own ranks-civil servants, who are supposed to maintain political neutrality.

title: Kith Founder Ronnie Fieg Carries Exactly 7 Items in His Carry-On
summary: "My carry-on is a very small bag, almost like a clutch...I've become a professional packer," says Fieg, who's on an airplane almost every week of the year. title: Saudi Arabia to Allow Women to Travel Abroad Without Permission
summary: Kingdom relaxes guardianship law following international scrutiny of the restrictions it places on women. Saudi Arabia has approved a new law allowing women to travel abroad without a male guardian's permission, senior Saudi officials said, ending restrictions that had been a symbol of the kingdom's ultraconservative rule.

title: Japan Ratchets Up Trade Dispute With South Korea
summary: Tokyo revokes South Korea's status as a preferential trading partner. Japan removed South Korea from a list of preferential trading partners, escalating tensions between two U.S. allies whose companies together supply key components used by U.S. technology companies such as Apple Inc. and Amazon.com Inc.

title: Some Want Delivery Drones to Buzz Off. Would Stricter Rules Change Their Minds?
summary: A trial in Australia thrilled some residents and annoyed others. A parliamentary report on that trial homed in on noise and privacy oversight.. Big rental-home owners, on the other hand, are overjoyed.

title: Lapse of Nuclear Treaty Throws Doubt on Future of Arms Control
summary: U.S.-Russia accord on intermediate-range nuclear forces lapses Friday; long-range agreement is set to expire in February 2021. The landmark treaty on intermediate-range nuclear forces lapses Friday, opening the way for a new generation of land-based missiles and casting a shadow over the future of arms-control agreements.

summary: Pinterest's strength caps a banner quarter for social-media players, proving the apps' users just can't quit. Say what you want about social media; it doesn't appear to be going anywhere.

summary: Resume Subscription. Toyota's cars are known for being practical and reliable, albeit without much character. The same can be said for the Japanese car maker itself, which delivered a stable performance last quarter despite the spluttering global auto market.

summary: Threat of more tariffs further clouds Beijing's efforts to manage its currency. China's yuan slid to its weakest level of the year, nearing the symbolic level of 7 per dollar, after President Trump threatened to impose more tariffs on Chinese imports.

title: 'My Role Is Not to Be a Shill for the IRS'
summary: Nina Olson, who is stepping down as the taxpayer advocate, reflects on nearly two decades of fighting the IRS on Americans' behalf. Internal Revenue Service commissioners have for years told Nina Olson she's not a team player. She doesn't care. That isn't her job.

As college admissions officers gear up for the first application season since learning of a broad cheating scandal, many are looking at how much effort they should put into catching liars-and concluding they aren't making big changes.

Saudi authorities have freed a Saudi-American doctor who was allegedly tortured while held in prison for almost two years without known charges, people with knowledge of his case said, ending a detention that had fueled criticism of Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman in Washington.

title: North Korea Fires Two Short-Range Projectiles
summary: Weapons test ratchets up pressure against the U.S. amid stalled nuclear talks. SEOUL-North Korea conducted its third weapons test in just over a week, launching a pair of short-range projectiles off its east coast on Friday, South Korean officials said, ratcheting up pressure against the U.S. amid stalled nuclear talks.

title: U.S. Drug Epidemic Becoming More Urban
summary: The drug epidemic is becoming increasingly urban, with death rates from overdoses in cities overtaking those of rural areas for the first time in years, according to CDC. The nation's drug epidemic is becoming increasingly urban, with death rates from overdoses in cities overtaking those of rural areas for the first time in several years, according to a new federal analysis published Friday.

title: Expected Surge in Oil Supply and Tariffs Add to Glut Concern
summary: U.S. benchmark for crude posts biggest drop in four years as Trump threatens new levies. Growth in oil supply is expected to accelerate next year as global production increases, keeping crude mired in a bear market and possibly lowering fuel prices for consumers.

title: Trump Organization Subpoenaed for Documents Related to Stormy Daniels Hush Payment
summary: Investigation relates to $130,000 payment former Trump lawyer Michael Cohen made to former adult-film star.
